Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Cultural Shift in Computer Science: Introducing Computation through E-Textiles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, in collaboration with the University of Colorado at Boulder, proposes a project to introduce computation through e-textiles. Computer science in the United States is an overwhelmingly male discipline. Many of the the crucial factors in this gender imbalance are cultural; that is, the culture that has grown up around computer science has a variety of attributes that appeal more to males than females. In response, this project seeks to design an alternative cultural pathway into the subject -- a pathway that does not purport to change or even implicitly criticize the existing CS culture, but rather seeks to provide a very different culture through which new populations (and especially females) can become fascinated with computing. Specifically, this project will develop and disseminate tools for engaging people in computing through the medium of fabrics and electronic textiles (or e-textiles). The work will build upon ongoing efforts to create accessible, powerful tools and materials that allow users to design and build their own programmable interactive fashion. The types of projects that users undertake within this alternative culture of computer science are rich in content, but refreshingly nontraditional: they are tangible, colorful, dramatic, richly interactive, and beautiful. This project proposes to encourage the growth of this new culture via two complementary avenues of work: the development of a visual programming environment for the LilyPad Arduino (a toolkit developed by the PIs that enables people to build e-textiles) and the development, dissemination, and evaluation of an "E-textiles in-a-Box" kit for educators. This kit will be disseminated through the large network developed by the National Center for Women and Information Technology (NCWIT) and its effectiveness will be assessed by NCWIT's social science team. These efforts are crucial next steps in engaging a broad audience in e-textiles and -- via this engagement -- a new and diverse audience in computing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A collaboration of the University of Colorado, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the National Center for Women & Information Technology, this project was intended to develop and disseminate tools for engaging people in computing through the medium of fabrics and electronic textiles. Based on some promising preliminary data, we had proposed that “e-textiles” could be a way for new populations, especially females, to become interested in computing.

 

Because of this project, hundreds of students and dozens of teachers, both male and female, were exposed to computing through new curricula delivered by team members and their associates in public middle school science, media and art classes; out-of-school-time programs; teacher professional development workshops; and do-it-yourself activities downloaded from the Internet.

 Evaluation data were collected several times throughout the project. In a series of out-of-school-time programs, middle- and high-school students showed moderate increases from pre- to post-survey in interest in learning more about computer programming, and statistically significant increases in comfort with programming on their own, and enjoyment of programming. Results showed that both girls and boys expressed similar levels of interest, comfort, and enjoyment before and after the workshops. Given that formal computing activities may often result in girls becoming less interested or engaged in computing, these non-discriminating results between genders is encouraging. In evaluation done on the in-school use of e-textiles, evaluation findings were less definitive. This may have been due to a lack of sensitivity in the instrument to that lower intensity setting and to the novice instructors.

 Along with new software that was developed to work with the Arduino Lilypad, our experiences and findings were shared via international academic conferences, peer-reviewed publications, and local media. An enduring outcome of this project is a free, downloadable step-by-step instruction kit for creating e-textiles (available at www.ncwit.org/etextiles). Based on the Computational Textiles Curriculum and Sew Electric from MIT, e-Textiles-in-a-Box provides instructions for sewing soft circuits and programming an Arduino microprocessor to create a bookmark book light and an interactive felt monster that lights up and sings.
